titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Associate Director, Office Files of Robert M. Hutchins
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Associate Director, Office Files of Robert M. Hutchins FA703
titlestmt.author: Arranged and described by Jim Moske, Ford Foundation Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-01 02:06:53 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Associate Director, Office Files of Robert M. Hutchins

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Robert M. Hutchins (1899-1977) was an educator, academic administrator and foundation leader who served as Associate Director of the Ford Foundation from 1951-1954. Hutchins was hired by the Foundation's new President, Paul G. Hoffman, to provide input on the development of grant portfolios related to education, civil liberties, civil rights and international cooperation. He played a key role in the establishment and early activities of three independent funds created by the Foundation: the Fund for Adult Education, the Fund for the Advancement of Education and the Fund for the Republic. Because Hoffman spent a great deal of time traveling during his tenure as President, Hutchins played a strong role in the overall administration of Foundation affairs and in managing the Pasadena headquarters. Hutchins left the Ford Foundation in 1954 to become President of the Fund for the Republic.

Prior to joining the Foundation, Hutchins came to prominence as President (1929-1945) and Chancellor (1945-1951) of the University of Chicago. He was a widely known, and frequently controversial, authority in the field of higher education. Hutchins was Chairman of the Board of Editors of Encyclopedia Britannica from 1943-1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Office Files of Robert M. Hutchins document the early development and implementation of Ford Foundation grant portfolios related to education, civil liberties, public television and refugee assistance during the years 1950-1956. The records provide insight into how Foundation staff and trustees acted on the programmatic recommendations of the Gaither Study Committee's Report of the Study for the Ford Foundation on Policy and Program (1949). They also offer a rare glimpse of the daily operation and administration of Foundation affairs under the leadership of President Paul G. Hoffman, when the institution was headquartered in Pasadena, California. The files contain correspondence with grant seekers, staff and trustees, reports by consultants and grantees, conference materials, staff memoranda, program planning information, meeting minutes, publications and clippings. The collection measures 4 linear feet and is contained in 12 archival boxes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Office Files of Robert M. Hutchins are arranged in two series:

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Filed here are incoming and outgoing letters, telegrams, memoranda and attachments that document the inception and early operation of Ford Foundation grant programs with an emphasis on fields overseen by Hutchins, which included education, civil liberties and cultural affairs. There is also substantial information concerning Foundation activities related to the promotion of international cooperation and refugee assistance.

Highlights include numerous letters and memos exchanged with staff that illuminate decision making processes and lines of authority as the five program areas delineated in the Gaither report were first implemented. Staff memos also contain valuable information regarding the administrative structure of the Foundation, the relationship between the Pasadena and New York offices, early public relations efforts, and internal reaction to investigations of the Foundation by the U.S. Congress's Cox Committee and Reece Committee.

Numerous letters from the philosopher Mortimer J. Adler document his influence on Hutchins's program in the field of education. Correspondence with editor and publisher James Laughlin shows that Hutchins and Foundation advisor W. H. "Ping" Ferry were each closely involved with Laughlin's work as head of the Foundation-supported Intercultural Publications and the journal Perspectives. Conditions facing European war refugees are discussed extensively in files on the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Finally, there are a small number of items that date from after Hutchins's departure from the Foundation, and which document the first months of his tenure as President of the Fund for the Republic.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These files are arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports, publications, clippings, conference and seminar materials, memoranda, meeting minutes and other records concerning Foundation grantees, programs and administration. There are substantial files documenting the inception of Foundation portfolios in the fields of public television, overseas training and research, academic exchanges and public affairs. Also filed here are records pertaining to the Fund for Adult Education and the Fund for the Advancement of Education. Additional records document the creation of policies and procedures for the day to day administration of Foundation affairs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These files are arranged alphabetically by subject.
